Green synthesis of functionalized iron nano particles and molecular liquid phase adsorption of ametryn from water
Imran Ali a,⁎, Zeid A. AL-Othman b, Abdulrahman Alwarthan b a Department of Chemistry, Jamia Millia Islamia (Central University), New Delhi 110025, India b Department of Chemistry, College of Science, King Saud University, Riyadh 11451, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: drimran_ali@yahoo.com, drimran.ch
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molliq.2016.06.089 0167-7322/© 2016 Published by Elsevier B.V.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 9 May 2016 Accepted 27 June 2016 Available online 29 June 2016
Second generation herbicide ametryn [2-(ethylamino)-4-isopropylamino-6-methyl-thio-s-triazine] is being used to control broadleaf weeds and annual grasses in sugarcane, bananas, maize and pineapple fields; contaminating water resources. The adsorption method of ametryn removal was presented using functionalized iron nano particles as adsorbent. This adsorbent was prepared by green method, functionalized with 1-butyl-3methylimidazolidium bromide and characterized by FT-IR, SEM and XRD techniques. Residual ametryn in water was analyzed by optimized HPLC. The optimized batch experiment parameters were 30.0 μg/L, 30.0 min, 7.0, 2.5 g/L and 20.0 °C as concentration, contact time, adsorbent amount and temperature. Adsorption data followed Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin and Dubinin-Radushkevich models. Thermodynamic parameter such as ΔG°, ΔH° and ΔS° were −6.05, −6.11 and −6.15 kJ/mol at 20, 25 and 30 °C temperatures; −6.68 kJ/mol and −2.45 × 10−3 kJ/mol K. These values indicated sorption spontaneous and exothermic. Pseudo-secondorder and liquid film diffusion mechanisms of the adsorption were proposed. Developed sorption method was speedy, environmental friendly and inexpensive due to its nature to be used under natural conditions of water resources. The method work at natural water resources pHs with low adsorbent amount and agitating time. The sorption method may be used for the removal of ametryn from any water body at large and economic scale.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Ametryn [2-(ethylamino)-4-isopropylamino-6-methyl-thio-s-triazine] is a second generation herbicide and used to control broadleaf weeds and annual grasses in sugarcane, bananas, maize and pineapple fields. Besides, it is also used to control general weed in potato crops. Additionally, this herbicide is also applied as a vine desiccant on dry beans and potatoes [1,2]. In this way, it is distributed globally in various water bodies. But it is toxic to human beings creating nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle weakness, salivation and cancer [3]. Besides, it creates irritation to the skin, eyes and respiratory tract. It is also toxic to terrestrial and aquatic animals [4,5]. Farré et al. [6] reported toxic nature of ametryn and its four degradation products. Briefly, ametryn and its biodegradation products are threats to the animals, human beings and ecosystem. Despite of useful application of ametryn, it is being contaminated water resources and soils. It has been reported in the ground water at many places in the world [7–12]; making water unfit for drinking, re-creation and other purposes. Therefore, the scientists, academicians, Governments and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) are very much worried about water contamination due to
iral@gmail.com (I. Ali).
ametryn. Hence, removal of ametryn from water is of the most importance. Literature survey dictates few adsorptionmethods of the removal of ametryn [13–18]. It was observed that these reported methods are not feasible to remove ametryn at large scale economically due to varied pHs, contact times, doses and temperature regimens. Therefore, a great demand of the removal of ametryn exists. Among various adsorbents [14–22], nano functionalized adsorbents are gaining importance continuously due to good adsorption capacities [23]. In this study, iron nanoparticles (INPs) were prepared by green method followed by functionalization by ionic liquid (1-butyl-3-methylimidazolidium bromide) [24]. The prepared functionalized iron nanoparticles (FINPs) were used for the removal of ametryn. Adsorption was optimized for fast, inexpensive, eco-friendly and reproducible method. Ametryn in water sample was analyzed by high performance liquid chromatography. The findings and discussion of this work is presented herein.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemicals, reagents and instruments
sections.text:
Ametryn was purchased from Ciba-Geigy Co., Greensboro, USA. 1- Butyl-3-methylimidazolidium bromide was obtained from Sigma-
Aldrich Co., USA. Acetonitrile of HPLC grade and acetic acid of A.R. grade were supplied by Merck India. Deionized water was prepared using Millipore-Q, Bedford, MA, USA system. The experiments were carried out on anHPLC system of Shimadzu, Japan consisting of solvent delivery pump (LC-10 AT VP), manual injector, UV–Vis detector (SPD-10 A) and Class-VP software. The column used was Nova-Pak C18 (150 × 3.9 mm) and obtained fromWaters (Milford, USA). The pHwas adjustedwith the pH meter (model 611, Orion Research Inc., USA). Philips PX-1830 diffractometer was applied to carry out powdered X-ray diffraction studies. The instrument was operated using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54 Å), a Cu filter on secondary optics, 25 kV voltage, 30 mA current and a proportional counter detector.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of and functionalization of nano adsorbent
sections.text: INPs were prepared by green method using black tea [25,26]. 100.0 g/L Black tea was impassioned in water at 80 °C for 1 h. It was filtered and the filtrate was used as reducing solution. Ferrous sulphate (200 mM) solution was added to tea extract in 1:2 ratios. The mixture was kept for 24 h; resulting in the formation of INPs. These INPs were separated and washed with deionized water three times. Furthermore, these were dried in an oven at 250 °C for 24 h. 5.0 g INPs were added to 100 mL solution of 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolidium bromide (2.5 g/ L) followed by agitation on a magnetic stirrer for 24 h. The FINPs were separated, washed with deionized water three times and dried in an oven at 100 °C for 24 h. These prepared FINPs were used for the adsorption for the removal of ametryn from water.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization of functionalized nano adsorbent
sections.text: FINPs were characterized using UV–Vis spectrometry, XRD and SEM techniques. The morphology of FINPs was developed by scanning electronmicroscope (SEM). The pictures of FINPswere achieved at different magnifications by operating with 10 kV operations. X-ray diffraction studies of native and functionalized INPs were ascertained by Philips PX-1830 diffractometer. The FINPs were scanned from 10° to 80° 2θ at a scanning rate of 3° 2θ per minute.

sections.heading: 2.4. Preparation of ametryn solutions
sections.text: Ametryn (100.0 μg/mL) solution was made in MeOH. The solution was kept in a freezer at −8 °C. The other diluted standards solutions for HPLC (0.50–80.0 μg/L) study and adsorption learning (10–50 μg/ mL) were prepared in methanol and water, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.5. Adsorption studies
sections.text:
The removal of ametryn was carried out in batch mode using thermostaticwater bath shaker. The FINPswere separated by centrifugation. HPLC was used to monitor equilibrium concentrations of ametryn. The adsorption isotherms were studied at 5–50 min contact time, 5–50 μg/ L concentrations, 1.0–10.0 pHs, 0.5–5.0 g/L dose and 20.0–30.0 °C temperatures. Thermodynamics and kinetics parameters were evaluated by differentmodels. Equilibrium concentrations of ametrynwere calculated using the following formula.
Ce ¼ Ci−Ctð Þ=m ð1Þ
where, Ci, Ct, Ce and m are the initial, at particular time (t) and equilibrium amounts (μg/L) of ametryn and weight of adsorbent (g/L). Percentage removal of ametrynwas determined by the following equation.
%Removal ¼ Ci−Ctð Þ=C0½ 100 ð2Þ
where, Ci and Ct have the usual meanings.

sections.heading: 2.6. Kinetics studies
sections.text: Kinetics profiles of ametrynwere done by uptake at various time periods. A range of concentrations of ametryn was shaken with known amount of FINPs till equilibrium. Residual ametryn was observed usingHPLC. Erlenmeyerflasks (100.0mL)with definite and known concentrations of ametrynwere shaken on thermostatic water bath shaker. The unchanging concentrations of FINPs were transferred to each flask with running shaking. The solutions were centrifuged and the supernatant was analyzed for ametryn. The blank experiments were carried out for determining the experimental errors.

sections.heading: 2.7. HPLC determination
sections.text: The different concentrations of ametryn were determined by HPLC as discussed above. 2.0 μL Ametryne (100.0 μg/mL) was injected onto HPLC machine in isocratic mode. The mobile phase used in this study was acetonitrile-water (65:35, v/v) with 4.5 pH adjusted with acetic acid. The detection was carried out at 250 nm.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of functionalized nano adsorbent
sections.text:
The confirmation of INPs preparation was done by observing any change in the peak area of tea polyphenols and caffeine at 205 and 275 nm. It was seen that that the peaks areas disappeared by mixing
ferrous ion solution; confirming the generation of INPs. SEM pictures (Fig. 1) of INPs reflected round shape (40–50 nm). The capping and reducing features of tea polyphenols and caffeine are responsible for INPs formation [24–26]. X-ray pattern (at at 27°θ) indicated the presence of iron oxide (Fig. 2). The peak of iron oxide disappeared on functioning by 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolidium bromide. This information confirmed the functioning of INPs.

sections.heading: 3.2. HPLC analyses
sections.text:
Ametryn was analyzed by HPLC on Nova Pak C18 column (150 × 3.9 mm) using mobile phase acetonitrile-water (65:35, v/v), adjusted to 4.5 pH with acetic acid, at 1.0 mL/min flow rate. Ametryn after batch experiment was confirmed by chromatogram of its standard. The
HPLC conditionswere optimizedusingmixtures of various alcohols, acetonitrile, hexane, diethylamine, acids. Besides, the effect of mobile phase pH was also optimized. The linearity was ranged from 1.0–50 μg/L. The coefficient of determination (r2) was 0.999 and LOD 10.0 μg/L.

sections.heading: 3.3. Adsorption optimization
sections.text:
The maximum uptake of ametryn was achieved by optimizing experimental variables. The various batch variables optimized were effect of concentration, agitating time, pH and temperature. The results of optimization are shown in Fig. 3. The findings of the optimization are described in this section. The concentration of ametryn was varied from 5 to 50 μg/L. The other batch conditions were contact time 30 min, dose 2.5 g/L, pH 7.0 and temperature 20 °C. Fig. 3a depicts the variation
itial conc., (b): contact time, (c): pH, (d): dose and (e): temperature.
of ametryn concentrations. It is evident from this Figure that uptake of ametryn raised from 5 to 30 μg/L. The maximum removal calculated was 88% of ametryn. The contact time experiments were carried out using 5.0 to 50.0 min as agitating times. Other parameters were 30.0 μg/L ametryn, 2.5 g/L adsorbent, 7.0 pH and 20 °C temperature. Effect of agitating time is shown in Fig. 3b and it is clear from this Figure that sorption increased from 5 to 30 min and become constant later on. The maximum uptake was 88% of ametryn. pH was varied from 1.0 to 10.0 (Fig. 3c). Other batch variables were 30.0 μg/L concentrations of atrazine, 7.0 pH, 2.5 g/L dose and20.0 temperature °C. It was observed that 7.0 was the best pH with maximum removal of 88% ametryn. Adsorbent amount was varied from 0.5 to 5.0 g/L with other batch variations such as 30.0 min contact time, pH 7.0, 30.0 μg/L concentration of atrazine at 20 °C temperature. The maximum removal was at 2.5 g/L (88% ametryn) (Fig. 3d). Temperature variation was with 20, 25 and 30 °C (Fig. 3e). The order of ametryn uptake was 20 N 25 N 30 °C; indicatingmaxim uptake of ametryn at 20. Briefly, the best batch conditions were 30 μg/L concentration, 30.0 min contact time, pH 7.0, 30.0 μg/L concentration of atrazine at 20 °C temperature.

sections.heading: 3.4. Modeling of adsorption
sections.text:
The uptake of ametryn was modeled using Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin and Dubinin-Radushkevich isotherms at three temperatures of 20, 25, 30 °C. The various equations of these models are given below:

E ¼ 1=√ −2βð Þ ð9Þ
Ct andQt are concentration and amount adsorbed of ametryn at time t. Xm (μg/g) and b (L/μg) are Langmuir constants. The values of Xm and b were calculated from slope and intercept of graph plotted 1/Qt vs 1/Ct (Fig. 4a). Langmuir isotherm described the results well. The values of Langmuir constants are given in Table 1, which confirm the applicability of this model. The dimensionless constants were 0.36, 0.25 and 0.16 at 20, 25 and 30 °C, temperature; indicating spontaneous sorption. n and kF [(μg/g)] are Freundlich coefficients related to relative adsorption capacities

Furthermore, these values also confirmed low sorption at high temperature. KT (L/g) and BT (kJ/mol) are coefficients of maximum binding energy and heat of sorption. The values of KT andBT (Table 1) confirmedminute variation in heat of sorption and strong interactions between adsorbate and adsorbent. qm and β correspond to degree and average energy of sorption per mole of adsorbate and can be calculated from intercept and slop of Fig. 4d. The E values were ranged from 1.80 to 2.00 kJ/mol (Table 1); indicating physical sorption.

sections.heading: 3.5. Adsorption thermodynamic
sections.text:
Free energy, enthalpy and entropy were calculated by-
ΔG0 ¼ −RTlnÅQ ð10Þ
lnQÅ¼ ΔS0=R−ΔH0=RT ð11Þ
T, R and Q° are absolute temperature (K), universal gas constant (0.008314 kJ/mol K−1) and Langmuir constant. Graph of lnQ° vs 1/T was a straight line (not shown). The intercept and slop connected to ΔH0 and ΔS0. The values of Free energy, enthalpy and entropy are given in Table 2. The negative free energy, enthalpy and entropy values indicated favorable, and exothermic sorption.

sections.heading: 3.6. Adsorption kinetics
sections.text:
The sorption kinetics was determined by the following models.
Pseudo-First-Order Kinetic
log Qe−Qtð Þ ¼ logQe−k1t=2:303 ð15Þ
Pseudo-Second Order Kinetic Model
t=Qt ¼ 1=hþ t=Qe ð18Þ
Elovich's Kinetic Model
Qt ¼ 1=β ln αβð Þ þ 1=βlnt ð19Þ
The equilibrium rate constant [k1 (min−1)] was calculated from slop of log(Qe − Qt) vs t graph (Fig. 5a). Pseudo-first order rate constant and regression coefficient (R2) were 0.085 (min−1) and 0.981 confirming this order model. The experimental and theoretical values of equilibrium amounts were 11.10 and 15.77 μg/g; with
29.6% higher theoretical value. This observation could not make pseudo-first order kinetic model as the best one. That is why pseudo-second order kinetic model was applied to the experimental data. Initial adsorption rate constant (h) was calculated from pseudo-second order Fig. 5b. k2 (rate constant) and Qe were calculated from intercept and slope of t/Qt vs t graph. The values of k2 was small as compared to h (Table 3) indicated speedy sorption initially followed by slow adsorption. The regression coefficient (R2) high value of 0.929 showed pseudo-second order model fitted to ametryn sorption. The closeness of practical and theoretical values of Qe was an indication of the well fitted data in pseudo-second order model. Adsorption and desorption were ascertained by Eq. (19) where α (μg/g/min) and β (g/μg) were adsorption and desorption rate constants. α and β values were 1.39 and 0.23 (Table 3) indicated higher adsorption rate than desorption. The regression constant was 0.889 showing the applicability of Elovich's kinetic model.

sections.heading: 3.7. Adsorption mechanism
sections.text: The sorption of ametryn to adsorption sites is studied by Eq. (20) (Qt vs t0.5). The rate constant was 2.86 μg g−1 min−0.5. Regression coefficient and intercept were 0.991 and 4.78 (Table 3). Graph line could not pass through the origin; showing non-applicability of intra-particle diffusion model. kfd and F = Qt / Qe are film diffusion rate constant and fractional attainment of equilibrium. Intercept and kfd values were 0.35 and 0.087 (Table 3). Besides, the straight line of ln(1− F) vs t graph deviated by−0.35 indicating nearness to the origin. This deviationmay be due to high agitation during batch experiments and disparity between rates of mass transfer in starting and last stages. Such deviations have been reported in various research papers [27–29]. Hence, uptake of ametryn is considered to be by liquid film diffusion mechanism.

sections.heading: 3.8. Regeneration of functionalized INPs
sections.text: The economic status of FINPs was ascertained by recycling. For this, regeneration of FINPswas achieved by treating it with acids such as HCl, HNO3 and H2SO4. Additionally, bases like sodium hydroxide and potassium hydroxides were also tried for regeneration of adsorbent. Besides, some bases such as phosphate, citrate, acetate were also tested for this application. After many experiments, it was observed that the best regenerating solvent was 10mNhydrochloric acid. It was capable to regenerate up to 99% functionalized INPs. The regenerated adsorbent could be used up to 7 batch operations with the removal capacities from 88 to 80%.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The developed functionalized INPs were effective for the uptake of ametryn from aqueous solution with maximum 88% adsorption. The
sorption was spontaneous with exothermic in nature. The optimized batch parameters were 30.0 μg/L, 30.0 min, 7.0, 2.5 g/L and 20.0 °C as concentration, contact time, adsorbent amount and temperature. Adsorption data followed Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin and DubininRadushkevich models. Thermodynamic parameter such as ΔG°, ΔH° andΔS° were−6.05,−6.11 and−6.15 kJ/mol at 20, 25 and 30 °C temperatures; −6.68 kJ/mol and −2.45 × 10−3 kJ/mol K, respectively. Pseudo-second-order and liquid film diffusion mechanisms of the adsorption were proposed. Developed sorption method was speedy, environmental friendly and inexpensive due to its nature to be used under natural conditions of water resources. The method work at natural water resources pHs with low adsorbent and agitating time. The sorption method may be used for the uptake of ametryn from any water body at large and economic scale.
